portfolio.title: Interactive Portfolio
portfolio.modalTitle: A modern, animated, React-based portfolio built to showcase my engineering approach, projects, and attention to UI detail
portfolio.alt: Person typing on a laptop displaying analytics charts and graphs. A vase of pink roses sits nearby on a wooden desk by a window with soft daylight.
portfolio.overview: This portfolio isn’t just a landing page — it’s a fully crafted mini-project designed to demonstrate how I approach UI architecture, animations, content structure, and interactive elements. The goal was simple: build a personal website that feels polished, expressive, and professional while giving a clear view of my skills.
whatIBuilt: Component-driven architecture using React and TypeScript with clear separation of concerns
Modular file structure inspired by Feature-Sliced Design for scalability and domain isolation
Reusable UI blocks: buttons, grids, cards, modals, layout components
Multilingual support (i18n) with HTML `lang` synchronization and a separate font for Cyrillic
State- and scroll-driven animations: GSAP for intro and scroll effects, Framer Motion for interactive modals
Scroll-driven project card animations with a 'View' tooltip that follows the cursor
Modal windows that block background scrolling and display detailed project presentations
Contact form with EmailJS for sending messages without a backend, featuring client-side validation, multilingual support, and a result modal
Fully responsive layout across all screen sizes (minor fixes for Safari/iOS: SVG icons, modals, header, hero section, footer tooltips)
Resume download available in three languages
Semantic and accessible markup with UX and ARIA considerations
Custom visuals generated for each project
Project fully covered by unit, integration, and end-to-end (Playwright) tests ensuring UI correctness and scroll/animation behaviors

challenges.challenge: Ensure proper multi-language support with HTML `lang` synchronization and a separate font for Cyrillic characters.
challenges.solution: Structured translations using namespaces and created a project configuration layer isolated from UI logic, simplifying multilingual support, content scalability, and correct Cyrillic rendering.

challenges.challenge: Create smooth scroll-driven animations for project cards on all screen sizes, with an interactive 'View' tooltip following the cursor.
challenges.solution: Used GSAP matchMedia with separate timelines for mobile, tablet, and desktop, and implemented the tooltip by tracking cursor position for a smooth and responsive UX.

challenges.challenge: Dropdown menus in the Skills section overlapped and broke UX when buttons were stacked vertically.
challenges.solution: Leveraged React Portals to render submenus above other elements, maintaining correct z-index and preventing accessibility and navigation issues.

challenges.challenge: Implement a working contact form without a backend, with validation, multilingual support, and proper error handling.
challenges.solution: Used EmailJS to send emails via a cloud service, connected my personal account and email. Added client-side validation using Zod, a modal to display submission results, and disabled the submit button during sending to ensure smooth and safe UX.

portfolio.stack: React 19, TypeScript, GSAP, Framer Motion, i18n, EmailJS, Jest, React Testing Library, Playwright, Vite, SCSS / CSS Modules

fintrack.title: FinTrack
fintrack.modalTitle: Full-Stack SPA for managing expenses, analytics, and personal budgeting
fintrack.alt: A laptop displaying code sits on a wooden desk beside a notebook with a pen, eyeglasses, a cup of coffee, a plant, and a stack of papers reading `Hello World`.
fintrack.overview: Originally planned as a compact frontend demo, this project was intentionally expanded into a full-featured application with authentication, analytics, CRUD operations, and a modular architecture. It includes two versions — demo and full-stack - to showcase both a pure SPA setup and integration with a custom backend layer, including authentication flows, session management, and server-side logic.
whatIBuilt: Feature-Sliced Design architecture with clear domain separation and isolated layers
Complete authentication flow: login, registration, demo user, refresh tokens, and persistent sessions
Data-heavy UI with tables, filtering, forms, and modal workflows designed for complex user interactions
Expense analytics with charts, widgets, and category/date-based filtering
Full CRUD for transactions and categories with reactive state updates
Custom backend layer on Node.js (json-server-auth) with JWT-based authentication, refresh token rotation, soft delete, and server-side filtering
CI/CD pipeline including testing, linting, build, and deployment to Vercel
Test coverage: Jest + RTL, unit, snapshot & integration tests, mocked API/store, fully isolated from backend

challenges.challenge: Implementing secure and persistent sessions using json-server-auth, which does not support refresh tokens out of the box.
challenges.solution: Extended the server logic with a custom refresh endpoint, refresh token rotation, and synchronized session state handling on the client.

challenges.challenge: Maintaining smooth state updates without unnecessary rerenders in a data-intensive interface.
challenges.solution: Reworked state management using Zustand with selector-based subscriptions to localize updates and reduce UI overhead.

challenges.challenge: Keeping the codebase scalable and maintainable as the feature set grew.
challenges.solution: Introduced Feature-Sliced Design with isolated layers, domain-oriented modules, and reusable UI components.

fintrack.stack: React 19, TypeScript, Zustand, Node.js, json-server-auth, Recharts, Framer Motion, Vite, Jest, React Testing Library

briaton.title: Briaton Catalog
briaton.alt: Dimly lit restaurant interior with several set tables, upholstered chairs, wine glasses, and candles, creating an elegant and intimate dining atmosphere.
briaton.overview: An interactive web catalog for an online lighting store, developed as a test assignment for the digital studio AffArts. The project focuses on pure JavaScript logic, dynamic data rendering, and rich UI interactions — without frameworks. Responsive layout is intentionally handled in a separate portfolio project; this one highlights JavaScript-driven functionality.
whatIBuilt: Dynamic rendering of product cards from JSON data
Product filtering by type and availability, sorting by price and popularity
Pagination for large catalogs
Interactive shopping cart with add/remove actions and live total recalculation
City-based stock availability displayed via tooltips
“Products of the Day” slider built with Swiper.js
FAQ accordion with controlled open/close behavior
Form validation and submission with success/error modals
Modular JavaScript architecture for maintainable and scalable code

challenges.challenge: Building complex client-side logic without using a framework.
challenges.solution: Split functionality into isolated modules and components, clearly separating catalog logic, cart behavior, filters, and UI elements.

challenges.challenge: Maintaining a smooth and understandable UI with many interactive elements.
challenges.solution: Integrated external libraries (Swiper.js, Tippy.js, JustValidate) and connected them to custom business logic via clean JavaScript.

challenges.challenge: Keeping catalog, filters, and cart state in sync without global state management.
challenges.solution: Managed state through local data structures and controlled DOM updates.

briaton.stack: Vanilla JS, SCSS, Swiper.js, Tippy.js, JustValidate

pawtastic.title: Pawtastic
pawtastic.alt: A couple lovingly cuddles a golden retriever puppy, their faces close and smiling softly. The warm, cozy setting conveys joy and tenderness.
pawtastic.overview: A responsive homepage for an online pet store, built with pure HTML and SCSS, with a strong focus on Pixel Perfect layout, accessibility, and performance. The project was developed from a Figma design as part of a professional web development course, incorporating bug lists, team lead code reviews, and client requirements.
whatIBuilt: Pixel-perfect layout implementation based on a Figma design (±10px tolerance)
Fully adaptive and elastic layout from 360px to 4000px
Semantic and accessible HTML5 structure
Modular SCSS architecture using the BEM methodology
Responsive layouts built with Flexbox and CSS Grid
Smooth animations and hover interactions optimized for performance
Retina-ready image optimization with lazy loading
SVG sprite usage and vector graphic optimization
Preparation for top Lighthouse performance scores

challenges.challenge: Maintaining pixel-perfect accuracy across a wide range of screen sizes.
challenges.solution: Designed an elastic layout system using Flexbox and CSS Grid with carefully calculated containers and spacing.

challenges.challenge: Adding animations without negatively impacting performance metrics.
challenges.solution: Used GPU-accelerated CSS transitions, optimized raster images, and predefined media dimensions to avoid layout shifts.

challenges.challenge: Meeting accessibility requirements while preserving visual design.
challenges.solution: Applied semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, proper focus states, and predictable interactive areas.
